Award.AwardTitle: NSF East Asia and Pacific Summer Institute for FY 2012 in China
Award.AbstractNarration:
This action funds Brian Damit of The University of Florida to conduct a research project, entitled "Determining how airborne bacteria die by high temperatures," during the summer of 2012 at Peking University in Beijing, China. The host scientist is Professor Maosheng Yao.

The Intellectual Merit of the research project is the first detailed experimental study to test an existing theory of how high temperature kills airborne bacteria. Pathogenic airborne microorganisms in bioaerosols pose a risk of infection. Recently, it has been shown that they can be killed by infrared radiation that exposes them to high temperatures for a short time. This research seeks to determine the inactivation mechanism by observing possible cell structure damage using transmission electron microscopy (TEM)and DNA degradation using gel electrophoresis. Escherichia coli, a Gram-negative bacterium, will be used as the model microorganism in these studies.

Broader Impacts of an EAPSI fellowship include providing the Fellow a first-hand research experience outside the U.S.; an introduction to the science, science policy, and scientific infrastructure of the respective location; and an orientation to the society, culture and language. These activities meet the NSF goal to educate for international collaborations early in the career of its scientists, engineers, and educators, thus ensuring a globally aware U.S. scientific workforce.

POR.DRECONTENT:
Airborne microbes (bioaerosols) transmit diseases like influenza and tuberculosis and are a danger to human health that must be addressed. Recently, we developed a technology that uses heat (> 840 °F) generated by infrared light to kill airborne bacteria and virus to greater than 99.9%. Although this technology has shown effectiveness in laboratory testing, how the microbes actually die and technology’s practical usefulness are not known. Therefore, in this study we completed two tasks to better understand the technology: (1) examination of bacteria death due to the infrared heating (2) testing the effectiveness of the device in killing environmental bacteria and fungi.

In Task 1, airborne bacteria (E. coli) were heated by the device and the resulting bacteria cells were collected. These samples were first analyzed with a high-powered microscope to determine whether the cells experienced physical damage. Unheated cells appeared to be intact but microscopy of the heated samples were inconclusive possibly due to the presence of byproducts released by the device during heating. Besides physical damage, the effect of DNA damage causing cell death was also studied. The integrity of the DNA extracted from heated and unheated bacteria was examined with a molecular biology technique that separates DNA based on size. Heating caused a decrease in the number of intact bacterial DNA which indicates that the device possibly kills microbes by DNA damage. For Task 2, a system was set up to sample ambient microbes after heating by the device. Against bacteria, the device reduced the airborne concentration by about 99% at the highest heating (410 °F) but it was less effective against fungi. Overall, in this research, we discovered two important findings: DNA damage is possibly responsible for the heat death of airborne bacteria and the device is able to kill airborne microbes in the real world. This work is currently being prepared for submission to Journal of Aerosol Science.

In addition to supporting the technical accomplishments, the NSF funding allowed me, a U.S. graduate student, to work in Beijing and obtain international research experience. These types of experiences are vital for the development of future American scientists and engineers in our increasingly globalized world. I became more aware of how research is conducted abroad and also established important international connections. To address broader impacts and outreach, I used my opportunity to advertise the benefits of international research during a seminar presented at the University of Florida on June 1, 2012. I also personally discussed this funding program with students I met at conferences and within my department. Finally, I wrote a blog detailing my experiences to excite future students about international research.
